verses.text: Let us now praise outstanding men, our ancestors in their generations.
verses.comment: Sirach begins a section honoring the forefathers, establishing the biblical tradition of remembrance of the righteous. This lays groundwork for thinking about communion with those who have gone before, which is also seen in Hebrews 11.

verses.text: The Lord created great glory through them, His majesty from the beginning.
verses.comment: This verse recognizes that the glory of faithful men is ultimately God's glory working through them. All human praise reflects God’s providence, aligning with the idea that grace perfects nature.

verses.text: They ruled in their kingdoms and were renowned for their power, giving counsel according to their wisdom.
verses.comment: The text subtly honors those endowed with authority and wisdom—echoes of Solomon and other biblical kings. This sets a precedent for spiritual governance and wisdom being respected in the community.

verses.text: They guided the people by their knowledge and wise words; they taught with understanding.
verses.comment: Education and teaching are shown as essential virtues. The respect afforded to teachers in Israel mirrors the position of spiritual instructors and tradition-bearers in the Church.

verses.text: Composers of musical verses, writers of poetry, and skilled in art.
verses.comment: The honoring of artistic gifts highlights the biblical affirmation of beauty and creativity as part of God’s plan—a foundation for the appreciation of sacred music and liturgy.

verses.text: Rich men furnished with resources, living in peace in their dwellings.
verses.comment: Material provision is acknowledged as a blessing, connected to peace—the biblical concept of shalom—which anticipates spiritual peace found in the faithful.

verses.text: All these were honored in their time and were a glory in their generations.
verses.comment: Generational honor illustrates the biblical principle of tradition—a spiritual inheritance passed down, which parallels apostolic succession in the life of the church.

verses.text: Some of them left a name behind, so that people declare their praises.
verses.comment: Remembrance of the righteous aligns with the biblical teaching that the memory of the just is blessed, and supports the spiritual practice of venerating the saints.

verses.text: But there are others of whom no memory remains; they perished as though they had never been, and their children the same.
verses.comment: A sobering reminder of human frailty and the importance of living a life worthy of remembrance in God’s sight.

verses.text: But these also were godly men, whose righteous deeds have not been forgotten;
verses.comment: The deeds of the righteous have eternal significance. This underlines the scriptural theme of merit and reward for charity and goodness.

verses.text: Their wealth remains with their descendants, and their inheritance with their children's children.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the ancient Jewish understanding of blessings as communal and generational, where the deeds of the righteous secure lasting inheritance for their descendants (cf. Genesis 17:7).

verses.text: Their descendants stand by the covenants; their children also, for their sake.
verses.comment: Honoring the enduring faithfulness to God's covenants, the text connects ancestral obedience with the continued religious fidelity of their children, reflecting Deuteronomy 7:9.

verses.text: Their offspring will continue forever, and their glory will never be blotted out.
verses.comment: Perpetuity of faithful lineage is emphasized, expressing the hope that righteousness leads to unending legacy and undying renown (cf. Psalm 112:6).

verses.text: Their bodies are buried in peace, but their name lives on generation after generation.
verses.comment: Burial in peace illustrates an honorable end, yet true immortality is found in a lasting, respected reputation remembered by future generations.
verses.sectionHeader: Praise of the Patriarchs: Enoch, Noah, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob

verses.text: The assembly declares their wisdom, and the congregation proclaims their praise.
verses.comment: Public recognition in the assembly underscores the communal nature of wisdom and praise in Israelite society, where wise lives form models for the whole congregation (cf. Proverbs 31:31).

verses.text: Enoch pleased the Lord and was taken up, an example of repentance to all generations.
verses.comment: Enoch's exemplary life (cf. Genesis 5:22–24) is recounted as a paradigm of repentance and divine approval, underscoring the importance of turning to God.

verses.text: Noah was found perfect and righteous; in the time of wrath he kept the race alive; therefore a remnant was left on the earth when the flood came.
verses.comment: Noah's righteousness preserved humanity (Genesis 6-9), illustrating God’s judgment and mercy, and the concept of a faithful remnant.

verses.text: Everlasting covenants were made with him that all flesh should never again be blotted out by a flood.
verses.comment: God's everlasting covenant with Noah (Genesis 9:8–17) promised that the world would not again be destroyed by flood, reinforcing divine reliability and mercy.

verses.text: Abraham was the great father of a multitude of nations, and no one has been found like him in glory.
verses.comment: Abraham’s status as the father of many nations (Genesis 17:4–5) highlights the universal scope of God’s promises and the singular honor attributed to him.

verses.text: He kept the law of the Most High, and entered into a covenant with him; he certified the covenant in his flesh, and when he was tested he proved faithful.
verses.comment: Abraham’s observance of God’s law and faithfulness under testing (Genesis 22) established him as the model covenant partner, with circumcision as the visible sign (Genesis 17:10–14).

verses.text: Therefore the Lord assured him with an oath that the nations would be blessed through his offspring; that he would make him as numerous as the dust of the earth, and exalt his offspring like the stars, and give them an inheritance from sea to sea and from the Euphrates to the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: The oath to Abraham assured the multiplication of his descendants and their inheritance (Genesis 22:16–18), underscoring God’s sovereign blessing through Abraham’s line.

verses.text: To Isaac also he gave the same assurance for the sake of his father Abraham. The blessing of all people and the covenant
verses.comment: Isaac, as Abraham’s son, inherits the same blessing, demonstrating God's faithfulness across generations (Genesis 26:2–5).

verses.text: he made to rest on the head of Jacob; he acknowledged him with his blessings, and gave him his inheritance; he divided his portions, and distributed them among twelve tribes. Moses: From his descendants the Lord brought forth a godly man, who found favor in the sight of all.
verses.comment: Jacob receives the covenant promises and passes them to the twelve tribes, culminating in the rise of Moses, through whom God fulfills His purposes for Israel.
